commentBody: Gimmick was neat enough. The clueing seemed a bit easy, maybe a bit over reliant on the theme. Fun (if a bit quick) Thursday.

"My mom's sister keeps ruining everything."
"Sounds like you have an aunt problem."

("Yeah, relatively speaking.")

Do you want ants? Because *that's* how you get (ten)ants.

Bravo Alexander!
At first I guessed LESSEES as the revealer before solving  any other clues, thinking maybe there’d be a fun puzzle with no E’s.  Not the most successful strategy.  Still a speedy Thursday.
"Thine" = "your" only when it precedes a noun beginning with a vowel; otherwise, it = "yours" (they're both pronouns; "your" is a possessive adjective, corresponding to the familiar "thy").
Love when I actually figure out the theme right away. Whole thing fell into place nicely; fun experience.
Appreciate LACUNAs crossing with COILs.
I like when the new words make sense on their own rather than ATLAA etc but it was fun

I enjoyed this puzzle a lot, and 50A is a terrific show which has earned mention.  

I think it was 28D where I began to suspect a rebus, so I ran with (ANT)LERs

But it all reminded me of something really embarrassing.

When I was in the sixth grade, I was a patrol boy for my elementary school.  I was elected to be the class's lieutenant.

But I couldn't remember how to spell lieutenant.  To many vowels an such.

So I visualized it as a command to a group of ants.  That is, "Lie, U ten ant(s)".  It seemed reasonable to trade "U" for "you" and to ignore the plural of ant, which, from what I learn from here, is anti.

Caught on to the rhebus and theme very quickly as I am a bit of an X-men fan and mut(ant)s didn’t fit into 1a. Then which square and which letters should be the rebus? I’m a huge reader and (ant)hology was another gimme. Ok, that’s one ANT. Are there insects or more ants. Working my way down the west side, I see hunting lodge decor, and not enough space for deer head but you can fit in (ant)lers. Made the rest of the puzzle  easy when I made ANT my m(ant)ra! First time ever I picked up the rebus so fast. Bested my average Thursday time. Also, as a Colorado mountain girl, not only did I enjoy ANTlers and ANTenna (appreciate using ant and antenna in this case), but it was another gimme for my home town AVS group to be the NHL
Not a fan of rebus  but enjoyable puzzle.

Was expecting ants in your pants somewhere but I liked 39A better,
Thank you.
Great puzzle!
Fun Thursday. Was really really hoping for a picture/emoji of an ANT in each box upon completion.
Well there we have it. The closest I've ever come to a Golden Month. Just missed one (the Saturday with AIRESDALE) this month
This was super fun! Figured it out with no help thanks to Donald Glover!

I enjoyed this puzzle a lot!  I figured out the rebuses easily enough.  I also needed less cheating than I did on yesterday's "Wednesday" puzzle.  Living in Arizona, I caught on to the 'state' not being in the US rather quickly.  But I didn't know the 1958 movie, despite being born in that year.  (I didn't do much movie watching then!)

Thanks for a fun one!

I was ready for this.  Clue one MUTANT knew we had a rebus.  

Not possible we have a continuance of our summer loving theme is it? 

After all those cookies and ice cream fell onto the floor, we got ANTS!!

The ants go marching two by two, hurrah, hurrah...

My first pass on across entries I had the correct answer appear immediately for most of the themes, but then it was the wrong number of letters so said to myself THISCANTBE. But then doing my first pass on downs, I had enough letters to guess TENANTS and suddenly a bunch of things made more sense lol. 

Also I was playing with alternate definitions for the ant words (ERR[ANT] is an ant making a mistake? ME[ANT]ALOT is Cookie Monster repeatedly having tiny friends for dinner) and the word "sextant" popped up. I really don't want to think about that ;)
I aced this without shredding the GNAR and learned a new expression and how to pronounce it. Fun, quick puzzle; trapped the ANT right away.

We all know Uncle Rebus, now there is Ant Rebus.

I thought the puzzle was clever and masterful.
Excellant!  (Although it seems I may still be a letter off.)

A MUTANT, an INFANT, and a PEDANT showed up for the open house, knowing they were competing with seven other ants for the lease.
The infant said “KIDDOS are really fun to have as neighbors.”
The mutant said “I’m really quiet since I’m part SNAKE”.
The pedant said “Actually, there aren’t any ANTS in this apartment, that’s just a suffix.”

The manager just sighed “THIS CAN’T BE.”

Ants ants ants! (Sprockets reference).

OK. Two ant poems. The first is by Virginia Hamilton Adair, a late-in-life poet who used to publish poetry in the 1930s-40s, then stopped for several decades, not liking the hustle and the egotism of that world, only taking it up again when her husband died by his own hand in 1990. Her book "Ants on a Melon" was a bestseller for a volume of poems. Here is the title poem:

Once when our blacktop city
was still a topsoil town
we carried to Formicopolis
a cantaloupe rind to share
and stooped to plop it down
in their populous Times Square
at the subway of the ants

and saw that hemisphere
blacken and rise and dance
with antmen out of hand
wild for their melon toddies
just like our world next year
no place to step or stand
except on bodies.

***

The second is by Robert Desnos from 1943, a poem for children about the outrageous lies they were told by the occupying Germans (the parallels to our current mendacious leaders are clear), called in French "Le Fourmi" (The Ant):

An eighteen-meter ant
With a hat on its head,
That doesn’t exist, that doesn’t exist.
An ant pulling a cart
Full of penguins and ducks,
That doesn’t exist, that doesn’t exist.
An ant that speaks French,
That speaks Latin and Javanese,
That doesn’t exist, that doesn’t exist.
Well! Why not?
Great ride!

Yarrrgggghhh, had it all solved except for 1D.  I was stuck on MICS and just could not figure out how to fix the cross at SNCLOSE.  I got lazy and took a revealer instead of brute-forcing it, and then felt shame.  Funny how one's mind (at least mine) can get stuck on something so clearly wrong when the right and not-so-harf answer is staring at you.

Pink panther theme is running through my head:
Dead ant, dead ant
Deadant deadant deadant deadant deadant Dead Ant…
Loved it! Figured it was a rebus early on. An accomplishment for me! Loved the clues. I am often awed by what constructors are able to do. Better than my average Thursday. Thanks!
This was so fun!!!
https://www.ispot.tv/ad/2NiX/geico-aunt-infestation Couldn't find that 10th ant, until err---

Picked up the infestation at square 4, and then continued stomping them out all over the grid. Didn't know how many til I got the revealer. I'd certainly rather have them invading my puzzle than my home, but it's Florida, so I've already had the pest control folks here doing some preventative maintenance.

Fun puzzle, Alexander, and thanks!

Had never done a rebus before.  Or knew what one was.  But I knew something was amiss.  

But when I did figure it out it was fun (and a little easier than usual)

Fun puzzle, figured it all out pretty quickly, but hearthbroken that all 3 letters were not accepted unless you use rebus - I put 'T' intead of A for all of the crosssections and lost my golden streak. Could have been handled better.
As an IDAHO native and lifelong skier (never in the White Clouds which I think are wilderness) I’ve never once said “shred the GNAR” but I guess there’s still time. ;) Thanks for a fun puzzle.

That was a good one. Somehow I put in "Sonoma" instead of "Sonora" thinking of a California county instead of a Mexican state. Also didn't know the cross "Ora." I figured out the "ant" rebus quickly but didn't figure each of them all out for a while.
I always thought the plural of lacuna was LACUNAE
FANTastic!

Tuesday-level puzzle with obvious rebuses.

3/10

Good Puzzle. Overly specific trivia. Best picture from a year in the the 50's? Brutal.

Also pretty sure mexico has provinces.

But still fun.

a pox on the pedANTic and devious 5D clue formulation which had me immediately assume an american state was being requested.  could only be nevada.  removing nevada for sonoma only came to me at the very end.
fun thursday.

I enjoyed the puzzle and managed to figure out it was a rebus pretty quickly. 

As for the ants, one of the best things I learned was do NOT smash them!  They release a pheromone that attracts others. I keep a spray bottle of part dawn, part vinegar and just give the scouts a squirt. It covers the pheromones and no more show up! I'm in Mississippi and it has worked wonders this year, every with as hot and wet as it's been.

I always know I’m having a stressful time in life when my crossword streak starts back up. This is the first time I’ve done a puzzle with a rebus and figured out the gimmick all on my own! I’m very proud of myself. I loved this one, I had a lot of fun.

PSA: Ants hate the smell of cloves. If they show up in your house, figure out their entry point and use cloves, clove powder, or clove oil mixed with water (in a spray bottle) around that area. It once worked beautifully for me. That said, the last thing I wanted to spread all over the grid was cloves. I wanted more ants! The more ants the merrier, so I Ieven popped in some Adam Ant for the full experience: https://youtu.be/meForQt7EK4?si=Qc2JGVy7fu11oXQo Loved every minute of it. Thank you so much, Mr. Liebeskind. Despite being infested, your puzzle has brought much joy!
Gigi won best picture in 1959.  It was released in 1958.  The Bridge Over the River Kwai won that year.

I have a TENANTScy to give up when I am too frightened to enter a fill that seems absolutely perfect and I see that somewhere there's got to be a missing rebus that will make it work. Or maybe there isn't and it's the wrong answer (that happened a lot).

Halfway through I realized I loved it, sort of like a yuletide Easter egg hunt, and it started to roll.  I needed something delightful tonight, and you gave me that , Alexander Liebeskind. Thank you!

(No need ask if you really were a love child.)

Great puzzle. Fun rebus. 

I wasn’t sure if the ANT in TENANT counted as one of the TEN ANTS. (It didn’t. DidANT)
Speaking of cool names for rock bands, I was tickled by the crossing answers of LACUNAS & COILS

Suber!

(Rebus is back!)
Loved this! Fun and I liked the concept and the distribution of thise ants throughout the grid. (Annoyingly reminds me of my house, little buggers.)
That one was faastic!
To all the plural pedants, lighten up! There is a reason the crossword column is titled “Word Play” and not “Oxford English Dictionary.”  The games afoot—let’s play!
Good stuff!

Arigato (thanks) for this fun crossword!
The crossword theme bears an uncanny likeness to a well known Japanese wordplay: There are ten ants. = Ari ga to.
ARI is Japanese for ant and TO is a way to say ten.
Insulting copy editors is rude. No, good copy editors aren’t pedants

As someone who is Chinese I’ve never personally seen a 37 across at Chinese New Year. Maybe it’s regional. Not particularly bothered but thought it’s worth pointing out. Or maybe that makes me a 15 across.

Color + black = shade
Color + white = TINTs

Had to look this up for my daughter recently

Took a few minutes to find my mistake.
VAA meant as much to me as FAA.
A deviant could be untameable....

First rebus completion ever and a very rare - for me - Thursday solve. Tweaked to it with ATLANTA and SANTA then got TENANTS and was on my way. And even rarer still - no frustrated Thursday rANT from me! ;>)

Unbelievably awful
Just a lookup puzzle
Obscure clues, which when revealed just elicits what?
Perhaps the worst crossword thus far.
Very enjoyable
My fastest Thursday ever!! I got the theme immediately, and things flowed well from there. I also liked how many rebus entries there were. Super fun!!
So many rebuses (rebi??) made it easier
007 Ocean’s Eleven came in handy.

I thought it might be interesting what AI could do with the ant theme. I requested  a poem that included words with 'ant' , including Antwerp and Bantu. The result:

A mutant ant with a curious plan,
Packed up his bags and away he ran.
“I’ll go to Antwerp, as fast as I can,
To learn to speak Bantu—I know that I can!”

The locals all stared at this bright little ant,
So eager, so keen, and so adamant.
He practiced each word with a marvelous chant,
While eating a waffle beside a tall plant.

An accountant nearby found it rather redundant,
To learn Bantu phrases in ways so flamboyant.
But the mutant ant twirled, so free and exultant,
And soon spoke in Bantu—quite clear and jubilant!

Wow. My first gold star on a rebus puzzle. I never thought that day would come. What a fun solve! This would make an excellent introduction to someone who's never heard of rebuses. Thank you for this memorable Thursday.
Lots of fun! Nice one

I was a little ANTsy when my Spidey sense signaled the presence of a rebus.  Luckily, no worries as it turned out to be a gentle one, especially once I realized that all the rebuses were ANTs.  I did, however, initially try mutes for 1A, thinking that maybe that was some sort of slang or short hand term for MUTANTS.

This was fun.

I initially thought comic would fit for 1A, but UDON proved otherwise.  I was pretty sure from the start that we would be looking for a Mexican state, but it took some crosses to get which one.

ROut before ROMP, spent some time trying to fit GIant into 35A and leANToES into 49D (there must be a spelling variant with an E, right?). The last ANT I found was in 26A.

I'm with Deb--no fan of ANTs in the house. In the puzzle, though? Nicely done.

I always like to see a rebus, and this is a perfect one to introduce the uninitiated to the possibility.  Hopefully, some new FANs were created today, and we won't see too many reviews like the clue for 62 D.

I'm my 62 years of skiing, some years more than 30 days on the snow, I have never heard anyone say, "shred the GNAR." Maybe I'm hanging out with the wrong crowd. Or I'm just old. 

Still, a fun puzzle. The rebus actually made it easier.
Rebus puzzles are a lazy tool of unimaginative puzzle writers. No fun involved and only frustrating.
Stop with the rebus. It’s not fun. It’s not interesting and it just makes for a horrible crossword..
Enjoyed the rebus element. But I tried to make the Oscar-winner GIANT 😂 eventually solved GIGI with the crosses.
Buoyant, brilliant, important, well-meant.  Blatantly, rampantly, triumphant!

Probably one of my favourite rebus puzzles. Took me a while to find the ANTS, then had a ball seeking the rest. DEvIANT held me up a tad. vAA made sense to me, though as DH is a pilot I really should know better. Went with c (Civil) AA first but clearly no feral, deviant DEFIANT type would include a c.
5D one of the last to fill as it never occurred to me the bordering state could be in a different country!

Deb; a spray bottle with half water half vinegar aimed at their entry point into your house does the trick. It disrupts the pheromones so they don’t have a trail to follow, but is still eco friendly, so no nasty pesticide to breathe in. Vinegar not the best odour in the world, so I spray the room with diluted essential oil afterwards.
My best Thursday time ever! I might be making progress.🌈
smoothest  rebus in a long time!  Almost at Tuesday puzzle!!

Fun times. It's interesting to reflect on just when the theme dawned on one.  For example, when you the first clue you KNOW to be true--but won't fit--surfaces... 

For me, that was 19A.  With OVEN and MICA solidly placed, it  just had to be DECANT, but couldn't squeeze that into the glass slipper!

So I thought "ok, leave off [AN]" and proceeded to think of the possibilities of [AN] holes throughout. Or LACUNAS, it would seem.

Didn't get a gold star, though, until turning them all into rebuses, after paying a visit to Ms. Amlen. Rebuses confuseses.

PS:  "lacunae" would have satisfied me better (more).

Perhaps a model for a Thursday puzzle. Got the rebus very early, and the revealer very soon thereafter. But found it a bit tough to fill a couple sectors of the grid. In the end, took me almost 20 minutes. 

Since today I've been invited to be a PED(ANT)---the clue for TALC is correct, since the mineral talc is indeed a main component of (the rock) steatite. However, MICA is a mineral (or member of a group of related minerals). So "Flaky rock" isn't really right, though it would be fine for mica schist, for example.
Fun Summertime puzzle!

I’m sure this has already been pointed out, but there are 11 of them. Not ten. The word beginning with “ten,” well, it is, by default, #11.

I’ll show myself out….

Really fun one. Happily, this one has the Handsome Family’s “So Long” prancing around in my noodle. Lovely! Not gonna be selfish. It’s too good… https://youtu.be/q4v3We9zqGI?si=qTDJ_w0X_hZ1khue Happy Thursday all!
Fun rebus puzzle!

Brilli(ANT) puzzle and a great introduction to the rebus for those unfamiliar with it. I saw the trick right away with 1A, but no idea where to put the 🐜 until solving some downs. I did erroneously try GI(ant)s for the Best Picture 🤪 until it became GIGI. And I can never remember if the OLSEN twins end in EN or ON. Otherwise, a fairly breezy solve. Thank you, Alexander. It was F(ANT)astic 😍
Such a fun solve! While the theme was on the easier side, the seamless fill and clues more than made up for it.

Ants are captains of industry, they always seem to be on task.  If you pick one up and place it down far from where you found it, it immediately goes right back to work.  Ants get things done.  They always seem to know what to do.  They seem absolutely in tune with the universe. 

We can learn from these creatures.

And be amazed as well, as I was after a quick ant fact hunt.  Ants are strong; they can lift objects 50 times their body weight. A super ant colony was found in South America that was nearly 4,000 miles wide.

Most of my experience with ants has occurred during three weeks in the spring, when they invite themselves into our house, and there is no keeping them out. They mean no harm; this is just part of their work, and when it’s done, they’re gone.

This puzzle was not only fun to fill in, it reminded me of a fantastic Barbara Kingsolver novel (“The LACUNA”). I also like how SARGE echoed the theme, because you can append ANT to it. 

Your puzzle, Alexander, happified my exercise-loving brain as well as sent me galavanting into Ant World.  What a blast – thank you!

Enjoyable rebus until I got to 49D "Huts" - the negative connotations around the use of that word in that way, especially apartheid South Africa in the 70s and 80s, evoked some bad memories. Maybe that's just me... 
Could have been clued as "Sailor rhythms" perhaps?

The plural of lacuna is....

...whatever the dictionary (and the crosses) say it is.

An excellent entry level rebus puzzle. And a fun one to solve! Like Deb, the last laugh was at FAN since GNAR and HANA were both TIL's. Brings to mind a personal hero: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._O._Wilson
A phrase that has stayed with me that I heard in a first semester American Lit class over 50 years ago was that true erudition is more than mere pedANTry

Cool puzzle. I sort of almost caught on to the theme early, but only the omission of AN before some Ts in some answers. Weird, but got me to fill the grid. Unfortunately no music since I didn't do any rebus stuff, it's still not something I'm used to in a crossword to be honest... After glancing at the column I felt a bit silly for not working it out, hopefully the early-morning is an acceptable excuse!
Thanks Alexander.
Kids level rebus.
Don't spray anything. Put out Terro bait. It works.

This might have been a bit too easy for a Thursday, but the clever rebus and revealer are compensation enough for the lack of crunch.  Hopefully it will convert some of the less-virulent rebus haters.

In my mind's eye, after solving the puzzle, the [ANT]s turned into animated bugs, who started crawling over the puzzle.
Is that too much to ask for, Techies?
"You want us to do that AND fix everyone's streaks?  There are only 24 hours in a day!"
The plural of LACUNA is LACUNAE. And LACUNAS. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/lacuna Can we move on now?
Is it just me or is there a mistake in the grid size? 43 down should be ‘dear santa’ but there’s not enough squares!
The plural of "lacuna" is "lacunae" not "lacunas".
I’ll be saying “Shred the GNAR” all day in my best Sean Penn from Fast Times at Ridgemont High voice.

A fun rebus puzzle. I didn't get any of the rebus clues until I got the revealer, but then I was able to quickly finish the top half of the grid and work through the rest. Rebus haters can stop rANTing, they're not going away, and I'm glad.
This was excellent.  Thank you.
I loved this puzzle.  Thank you!

An enjoyable Thursday, just the right amount of challenging…

ANTs reminds me of one of my earliest memories. I was three or four; we were living in Texas in the late 50s because my father was in the Navy as part of the “doctor draft” following the completion of his residency. One morning, my mother told me and my younger sister, “Don’t sit on the porch.” We did … and learned the hard way that one should avoid fire ants.

Have you noticed over the years how grasshoppers don’t really pull their weight, crossword-wise? I mean, these 10 ants are doing the work of 20 ants.

A good, hard-working-but-fun puzzle.

This one really nails the landing.  TEN ANTS is a terrific revealer!

I'm always a happy camper when there's a rebus -- and I especially applaud this one for its theme density.  Ten is a large number of ANTS to embed.  And the more ANTS you have, the more likely it will be that some of them will stymie the solver -- at least for a moment.  Now ANTS does happen to be a letter combo that appears in many, many words -- but you try embedding them 10 times.  Which of course means 20 times when you take both Across and Down into consideration.  Impressive.

Although I know nothing about the X-Man, I nevertheless picked this up at 1A: MUTANTS.  I owe it all to ANTHOLOGY, of course.  And because this one was the first rebus, it was also the hardest for me.

Toughest answer for me: MCLAREN.  Favorite clue: REGATTA.  Biggest "Huh???":  Shred the GNAR, whatever in the world that means.

Very enjoyable Thursday.  Bring on the rebuses -- I can never get enough of them!

Dang, all these comments about how easy this puzzle was and I'm sitting at 50% over average for a Thursday. For some reason rebuses (rebi?) don't click naturally in my brain yet - I saw the pattern but figured letters were just being dropped, so had half-fills that didn't make sense throughout the grid. I finally had to focus down the revealer and then the rebus clicked. When  you're not on the wavelength, you're not on the wavelength, I guess.

Haven't read all the comments yet, so apologies if I'm repeating someone else... I noticed while working out the puzzle on my (Android) phone that when I entered ANT for the rebuses, the keyboard autofill feature offered to replace the string with an ant emoji: 🐜.

Anybody else see that? I'm annoyed only that I didn't accept the hint -- it would've been fun (sorry, Deb) seeing the little critters infesting the grid!

My favorite ANTs (aside from this puzzle) are the "leaf-cutter" variety.  I had a "Little Pinky" rose bush at the far end of my big asparagus bed back in Arkansas.  Every year I could watch a parade of tiny ANTs, each one carrying a little parasol cut from a  pink rose petal, marching tirelessly down the wooden beam of the bed, taking the harvest down into the underground network where it would become part of the food supply.  (I think they grew fungus or something, but they never said...)  

Oh, the puzzle.  PED(ANT) gave it away...the rest was a ROMP.
I just love Alex Liebeskind's puzzles!

....and they all go marching 
down
 into the ground 
to get out 
of the rain
booom, boom, boom

Admiring my puzzle, 9D solution (snicker) could read “Wordplay comments section” (rant rack). And 45A could read “One final reminder of Oreos” (milk)

From goddess, to Hurricane, to Sherlock’s outwitter, to Goodnight girl, it's always nice when Irene makes a cameo. Good to see her again.

Kristen Wiig was Vera’s doppelgänger, once upon a time, she kind of still is. Vera… there's a name to embrace… from Wang, to Norm’s wife and aloe. C’mon. OK, I milked that one.

That ever-so-common laptop accessory had me thinking mics, probably along with everyone else here, too. Even with built-in trackpads? And, isn't meeces the plural of mouse, or is that plural for moose? I'll stay out of the plurality debate, as I'm sure it's ongoing over yet another mis-clue.

I’ll not debate the formality of RECON either. Ranger school had drilled in “scouting” out enemy activity while on a “recon” mission. But that's outside any scope of this rant rack…anyhoo.

“Absorbed a cost” and “filled up”  mean the same thing. Waaaow. I need a break from crossword puzzles, I'm starting to understand waaaay too much here.

What mantra does a realtor fall back on when a less desirable location is available, (especially in this housing market)? Discuss, I'm too verklempt.

Two thumbs up. A perfect Thursday is when catching on to the trick is the big turning point and this was certainly one of those days. Really impressive piece of construction too. Just can't imagine what it took to work all of that out. A couple of unusual puzzle finds today. First... a Sunday from July 15, 2012 by Randolph Ross with the title -"A" Trip around the world -. First theme clue and answer was: "Four stops with "A" trip around the world:" AFRICASIARGENTINARUBA Next one was: "Three more stops." ATLANTALMAATANDORRA And some other answers with the same kind of clue; AMERICARIZONALBANIA ALGERIALABAMARCADIA ALBERTALAMEDASTORIA ANTARCTICALASKANTIGUA And there more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/15/2012&g=26&d=A I'll put my other puzzle find in a reply. ...
Thank you, Mr. Liebeskind, for making me happy that I have ants in my kitchen. Excellent Thursday puzzle.

Seen on side of pest control truck:

"We Make Ants Say Uncle"
Brilliant puzzle. Possibly my favorite Thursday ever!

I had a first grade teacher who read us Leiningen Versus the Ants  during one of our story times. I'm not sure what lesson that was intended to instill in us, but I still can't unsee the vision it created.

Heh, LACUNAS shows up just one day after a puzzle in which my first-pass guess was “lacunae” for a similarly worded clue whose actual answer turned out to be VACUUMS. I dutifully went the “nature abhors…” route this time, only for crosses to yet again prove me wrong. Maybe tomorrow there will be yet another similar clue, but this time using my preferred plural form in the answer.
Super fun! Found the ANT in the ULQ immediately, but what fun to find 9 more through the puzzle!
Just want to add my voice to the praise this puzzle is receiving. Next time NYT puts together a pack of rebus puzzles or a book of Thursdays, this should be first in line. Great work!

I had a small spot of trouble in the SE corner, not knowing the Formula 1 clue, but I got a toehold with shanties and forged onward.

I found the theme clever and fun. The revealer briefly eluded me as I confidently entered "renters" but clearly couldn't read it as two words. I had been suspecting a rebus, and suddenly it all fell into place.

Great puzzle!
Rebus bad
It’s a clever design but it’s difficult for those of us who do the xword on the app, not on paper  - kinda hard to put more than two letters in a digital square.  Any suggestions?

I used to live in a basement apartment which suffered a wave of invasions by various insects, one of which was ants. I don't like to use pesticides, but I ended up using a certain poison that the ants take back to their queen, who eats it and dies. I am the bug assassin.

Anyway, this was a great puzzle. I found it pretty difficult, even without the rebus. There was lots of great fill: LACUNAS, GIGI, REGATTA. Thank you to the constructor and editors!

Now that I think of it--did yesterday's Oreos attract all these ants?
As soon as I detect that the puzzle is a rebus, I stop solving it immediately. Absolutely hate them.
I was thinking that the answer key might have ants in certain squares
How do you enter more than one letter in a square? New to online puzzles, today’s is solved except I need to be able to enter “ant” into one square, obviously.
This was the very first Thursday crossword where I figured out the f[ant]astic Rebus myself, without having to consult help online. Great puzzle, I enjoyed it a lot!!

As a longtime Formula 1 fan, I was pleasantly surprised to see MCLAREN appear in the puzzle. I guess the constructor has been watching "Drive to Survive" on Netflix. Next season promises to be amazing, with all the drama at Red Bull (which also fit in 45D) and the current crop of rookies in the sport.

Papaya Rules are in effect.

I don’t usually comment, but I loved this one today! Good balance of tricky and straightforward clues so that it was interesting but not “bang my head against the wall frustrating”, and I could get the ones I had no “clue” about on the crosses. @Al  in Pittsburgh 

That's one where thine = yours.

What came to mind for me is "To thine own self be true" ... thy(self) becoming thine. It's not whether the noun starts with a vowel, just the next word, which is usually a noun (because "thy" belongs to a noun; it's not a standalone) but can occasionally be something else, like an adjective. 

It's the same rule that governs "a" vs "an". And with the same rule about being the following word (so "an apple" but "a single apple"). And kinda for the same reason-- thy and a both end in vowel. (We don't do the same with your/her/his because they don't, but archaically my turns into mine.

Fun fact: the word for napkin is related to the word for apron -- both from "nape", table cloth, plus diminutive suffix. Apron used to be "napron", but then people started parsing "a napron" as "an apron".

@Fact Boy

@Isabeau The uses of “thy/thine” are quite similar to “my/mine” if you allow a little archaism: “my cat” / “thy cat”, “mine eyes” / “thine eyes”, “what’s mine is thine” / “what’s thine is mine”.

@Deb Amlen
We used to live in a 16C ropemakers cottage; the ant intrusion was horrendous with wonky doors and windows. I sprayed every door frame, window frame, the edges of the counter top in the kitchen and put little cotton wool pads sprayed with the stuff in the cupboards every day. I found their main entry points (two windows and the back of the sink pipes) as those areas would get a lot of ants milling around. I was told this was because the vinegar blocked their pheromone path and they were effectively lost. Once I concentrated on those areas, the house was ant free within a week. It’s a pain while you go through the spraying process, but it worked quickly for us. Good luck ejecting the little blighters.

@Roberto Of course “ants” is a count noun. You can count them. Sand is not a count noun, but GRAIN of sand is a count noun. Water is not a count noun, DROPS of water is a count noun. Just because people usually talk about them in the aggregate does not mean it is grammatically a non-count noun. Consequently, you shouldn’t say, “there are less ants,” you have to say “there are fewer ants.”
